qa_list.question: How many Independent Studies can a student take during their MLT coursework?
qa_list.answer: Only one Independent Study is approved for a student’s MLT coursework.

qa_list.question: What happens if an equivalent graduate course was completed at another institution? Can it be used to satisfy the MLT course requirements?
qa_list.answer: Yes, an equivalent graduate course previously completed at another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the MLT course requirements. The decision is made by the MLT Program Director.

qa_list.question: How many units are required for a student to complete their MLT coursework?
qa_list.answer: A minimum of 96 units of coursework at CMU is required for all MLT students.

qa_list.question: Can MLT students engage in internships? If so, under what conditions?
qa_list.answer: Yes, MLT students may only engage in internships if their advisors recommend it. International students must consult with the Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract.

qa_list.question: What should a student do to protect themselves from potential intellectual property problems during an internship?
qa_list.answer: Students are cautioned to be aware of potential intellectual property (IP) problems with internships and to review any IP agreements with their advisors before signing them. It is possible to lose ownership of your ideas.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they want to engage in external employment or consulting?
qa_list.answer: See also section 4.2.3, External Employment/Consulting.

qa_list.question: When can students request to transfer into the MLT program?
qa_list.answer: Students may request to transfer into the MLT program after completing their first semester.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for a student who wants to transfer from an LTI degree program to the MLT program?
qa_list.answer: The student must make the request in writing (or email) to the MLT/PhD Admissions Chair. The MLT/PhD Admissions Chair will inform the student about what application materials are required; for example, an explanation of why a transfer is desired, a proposed plan of study, a proposed advisor, and CMU transcripts.

qa_list.question: Are students allowed to transfer out of the MLT program?
qa_list.answer: Yes, the MLT program does not prevent students from transferring to another degree program. Each degree program has its own rules about whether and when transfers into the program are permitted.

qa_list.question: What should a student do if they want to transfer out of the MLT program?
qa_list.answer: The student that is interested in transferring out of the LTI degree program should consult the handbook and Program Director of the desired degree program.

qa_list.question: What are the procedures for adding, dropping or withdrawing from courses at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Students taking undergraduate and Masters’ level courses must follow the procedures and deadlines for adding, dropping, and withdrawing from courses as identified on the academic calendar.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about course changes at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Information can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/course-changes.index

qa_list.question: What is the statute of limitations for making changes to a student's course schedule?
qa_list.answer: There is no specific mention in this text about a statute of limitations.

qa_list.question: Why do MLT students not normally serve as Teaching Assistants (TAs) at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: MLT students do not normally serve as TAs because they need to get the approval of their research advisor if they want to TA a course.

qa_list.question: What is required for graduate students to instruct in Pennsylvania, according to the English Fluency in Higher Education Act of 1990?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students are required to have a certain level of fluency in English before they can instruct in Pennsylvania.

qa_list.question: What is the role of Language Support in the Student Academic Success Center at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Language Support evaluates and certifies the English fluency of all instructional personnel, including teaching assistants and interns.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of administering the International Teaching Assistant (ITA) Test at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The ITA test is a mandatory screening for all non-native speakers of English to determine their fluency level.

qa_list.question: What does the Student Academic Success Center offer to teaching assistants who are non-native English speakers at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The center helps these teaching assistants develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully.

qa_list.question: What is the 'Grandfather' policy in LTI Academic Policies at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: A student can graduate under the policies in effect at the time that the student entered the program or, at their choice, they can graduate under policies adopted after entering.

qa_list.question: What is the rare situation where a department may approximate a policy as closely as possible?
qa_list.answer: This occurs when a student is enrolled in the program for an extended period of time and it's not realistic to follow a particular policy exactly.

qa_list.question: What does 'approximate' mean in this context?
qa_list.answer: To approximate means to make something as close as possible, even if it can't be made perfectly the same.

qa_list.question: Why would a student choose to graduate under policies adopted after they entered the program at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: A student might choose this option because they believe that these new policies offer better opportunities or benefits.

qa_list.question: What are the two options for a student to graduate under according to the policies in effect at the time they entered the program?
qa_list.answer: A student can either graduate under the policies that were in effect when they started or choose to graduate under new policies adopted after their entry.

qa_list.question: What happens if it's not feasible for a student to follow a particular policy exactly?
qa_list.answer: In rare cases, where the student is enrolled in the program for an extended period of time, the department may approximate the policy as closely as possible.

qa_list.question: What does LTI stand for and what decision do they make regarding transfer credit or course exemption?
qa_list.answer: LTI stands for Learning Technology Initiative. They grant either transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution, the decision rests with the chair of the particular program.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student is exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience?
qa_list.answer: If a student is exempt from a required course, they can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student receives credit for prior coursework completed at CMU or elsewhere?
qa_list.answer: If a student receives credit for prior coursework, they receive that many units of credit and their total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.

qa_list.question: What does MLT stand for in the context of this text?
qa_list.answer: MLT stands for Master's Learning Technology Initiative Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: On what page can you find information about transfer credit versus course exemption?
qa_list.answer: You can find this information on Page 23 of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What are the expectations regarding external employment and consulting for students funded by LTI research projects?
qa_list.answer: Students funded by LTI research projects are normally expected to work exclusively for those projects. They are generally permitted to consult, at most, one eight-hour day per seven-day week, only with the advisor's consent. International students must also have approval in advance from the Office of International Education (OIE); otherwise, they may be in violation of their visa status.

qa_list.question: What is the policy on Leave of Absence for LTI students?
qa_list.answer: The LTI discourages Leaves of Absence (LOA), since students usually do not return, despite good intentions. However, a student in good standing may be granted a LOA of at most 1 year, upon written request to the Program Director and with consent of the student's advisor.

qa_list.question: What happens if an LTI student does not make satisfactory progress each semester?
qa_list.answer: If a student does not make satisfactory progress each semester toward completing the degree, the LTI may remove the student from the program. See section on 'End of Semester Evaluation'.

qa_list.question: What are the expectations for students supported by research projects during winter and summer breaks?
qa_list.answer: Students supported by research projects are expected to remain on campus working during breaks in classes. A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer. The normal winter break policy is that the student works 40 hours per week for two weeks, and takes vacation for the other two weeks.

qa_list.question: Where can students find assistance if they have disabilities at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Students with disabilities can seek assistance from http://www.cmu.edu/disability-resources

qa_list.question: What is the policy for winter break in terms of work hours and vacation time?
qa_list.answer: The normal winter break policy is that students are expected to work 40 hours per week for two weeks, and take vacation for the other two weeks.

qa_list.question: What resources does Carnegie Mellon University provide for individuals with disabilities?
qa_list.answer: The Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University provides physical and programmatic campus access to all events and information within the Carnegie Mellon community. They work to ensure that qualified individuals receive reasonable accommodations as guaranteed by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973.

qa_list.question: How many weeks is a typical summer vacation at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer.

qa_list.question: What should students supported by research projects do during breaks in classes?
qa_list.answer: Students supported by research projects are expected to remain on campus working during breaks in classes.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about accommodations for individuals with disabilities at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students who would like to receive accommodations can begin by visiting the Office of Disability Resources at http://www.cmu.edu/disability-resources.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The mission of the Office of Disability Resources at Carnegie Mellon University is to provide physical and programmatic campus access to all events and information within the Carnegie Mellon community.

qa_list.question: What does the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) guarantee?
qa_list.answer: The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) guarantees reasonable accommodations for qualified individuals.

qa_list.question: How many weeks of vacation are allowed during a typical winter break at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Two weeks of vacation is typically allowed in the winter break.

qa_list.question: What does Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 guarantee?
qa_list.answer: Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 guarantees reasonable accommodations for qualified individuals.

qa_list.question: What are the circumstances that may warrant a grade appeal?
qa_list.answer: The circumstances that may warrant a grade appeal include manifest error (e.g., a clear error such as arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam) and violation of University policy.

qa_list.question: Who has the discretion to assign final grades?
qa_list.answer: Final grades are assigned by the instructor, who has sound discretion in grading.

qa_list.question: What is the process for changing a student's final grade?
qa_list.answer: Final grades will be changed only in exceptional circumstances and with the approval of both the instructor and the department, unit, or program.

qa_list.question: Who must give their consent before a student's final grade can be changed?
qa_list.answer: The instructor who assigned the original grade must give their consent for a student's final grade to be changed.

qa_list.question: What is the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The MLT Graduate Student Handbook is a guide that provides information about academic policies and procedures, including those related to grading and appeals.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about the grade appeal process at their university?
qa_list.answer: Students can find more information about the grade appeal process in the MLT Graduate Student Handbook, specifically on page 25.

qa_list.question: What is the role of a department, unit, or program in the grade appeal process?
qa_list.answer: A department, unit, or program plays a crucial role in the grade appeal process by providing additional review and approval before final grades can be changed.

qa_list.question: What is manifest error in grading?
qa_list.answer: Manifest error in grading refers to clear errors such as arithmetic mistakes or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam.

qa_list.question: Can a student appeal their final grade without any exceptional circumstances?
qa_list.answer: No, students cannot appeal their final grades unless there are exceptional circumstances that warrant a change, such as manifest error or violation of University policy.

qa_list.question: What are the issues that Carnegie Mellon University prohibits according to their Sexual Misconduct Policy?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University prohibits sex-based discrimination, sexual harassment, sexual assault, dating/domestic violence, and stalking.

qa_list.question: Where can students find the University's Sexual Misconduct Policy?
qa_list.answer: The University’s Sexual Misconduct Policy is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/sexual-misconduct/index.html.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they have been impacted by any of the issues mentioned in the text?
qa_list.answer: Students who have been impacted by any of these issues are encouraged to make contact with any of the following resources: Office of Title IX Initiatives, University Police.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for Carnegie Mellon's Policy Against Retaliation?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon’s Policy Against Retaliation is available at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/administrative-and-governance/whistleblower.html.

qa_list.question: What resources and information can be found on the website provided in the text?
qa_list.answer: Additional resources and information can be found at: https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/resources-and-information/resources.html.

qa_list.question: What is the URL for Carnegie Mellon's Gestational and Parental Accommodation protocol?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon’s Gestational and Parental Accommodation protocol can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/graduate/programs-services/maternity-accommodation-protocol.html.

qa_list.question: What should students do to register for any of the parental accommodations described in the text?
qa_list.answer: Students seeking any of the parental accommodations described must register with the Office of the Dean of Students by contacting the office for an appointment by calling 412-268-2075.

qa_list.question: What is Carnegie Mellon's top priority according to the text?
qa_list.answer: Providing holistic student support is a top priority at Carnegie Mellon.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about parental accommodations described in the text?
qa_list.answer: More information about the parental accommodations can be found on this page: https://www.cmu.edu/title-ix/resources-and-information/resources.html.

qa_list.question: What is short-term accommodation for gestational parents?
qa_list.answer: Short-term accommodation for gestational parents refers to a temporary absence from academic responsibilities, up to a maximum of six weeks. This can be extended by two weeks for a total of eight weeks if medically necessary.

qa_list.question: What is the Student Leave Policy?
qa_list.answer: The Student Leave Policy allows students to take a leave of absence for a full-semester, mini-semester, or for the time remaining in the semester during which the leave is taken. Students who take a Formal Leave of Absence drop all their courses and are unenrolled from the university.

qa_list.question: What financial assistance options does Carnegie Mellon offer for student parents?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon offers an interest-free loan to any student who becomes a parent while enrolled. This loan can be applied for through the Office of the Dean of Students.

qa_list.question: What are the implications for international students considering a Formal Leave of Absence?
qa_list.answer: International students must consult with the Office of International Education before considering a Formal Leave of Absence due to visa implications.

qa_list.question: What is 6.1 Graduate Student Funding in Carnegie Mellon's financial assistance options?
qa_list.answer: 6.1 Graduate Student Funding refers to the various funding opportunities available for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon, including assistantships, fellowships, and loans.

qa_list.question: What is an interest-free loan?
qa_list.answer: An interest-free loan is a type of financial aid that does not charge the borrower any interest on the amount borrowed. In Carnegie Mellon, this option is available to students who become parents while enrolled.

qa_list.question: What are some adjustments that must be made by a student before taking short-term accommodation?
qa_list.answer: Before taking a short-term accommodation, students must work with relevant university faculty and staff to adjust their coursework, research, teaching, and other academic responsibilities during the period of absence. This may include extensions of time to complete assignments, incomplete grades, dropping courses, shifting research responsibilities, and adjusting TA assignments.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum duration for a short-term accommodation?
qa_list.answer: The maximum duration for a short-term accommodation is six weeks. It can be extended by two weeks for a total of eight weeks if medically necessary.

qa_list.question: What happens to students who take a Formal Leave of Absence?
qa_list.answer: Students who take a Formal Leave of Absence drop all their remaining courses for the semester and are unenrolled from the university.

qa_list.question: What kind of financial assistance is available for students who become parents while enrolled at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon offers an interest-free loan to any student who becomes a parent.

qa_list.question: Who is eligible to apply for the interest-free loan from the Office of the Dean of Students at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Any student who becomes a parent while enrolled at Carnegie Mellon University can apply for an interest-free loan.

qa_list.question: What kind of funding is guaranteed for all LTI MLT students in their first year at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: For all LTI MLT students, full funding (tuition plus stipend) is guaranteed for the first year.

qa_list.question: What does the fellowship include for LTI MLT students at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: The fellowship includes full tuition and fees, and a monthly MLT stipend.

qa_list.question: Does Carnegie Mellon pay a dependency allowance to LTI MLT students with children?
qa_list.answer: Yes, the LTI pays a 10% of the student's monthly stipend as a dependency allowance to any student with a child.

qa_list.question: What happens if an MLT student receives an outside graduate fellowship?
qa_list.answer: If an MLT student receives an outside graduate fellowship, they are expected to accept it in place of the LTI’s graduate fellowship.

qa_list.question: What is the extra incentive provided by the LTI for MLT students who receive an outside graduate fellowship?
qa_list.answer: The LTI will supplement the award so that the student will receive full tuition and a combined MLT stipend.

qa_list.question: What is the page number where this information can be found in the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: This information can be found on Page 27 of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the stipend for graduate students in LTI?
qa_list.answer: $10 percent higher than that of the standard LTI graduate fellowship.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find information about financial aid?
qa_list.answer: They should consult the graduate student financial aid information found on The HUB website: http://www.cmu.edu/finaid/graduate/index.html.

qa_list.question: How is travel funding provided for students who are not funded by a research project?
qa_list.answer: Students who have no project funding may be provided with partial funding, with a larger amount available for travel to present a refereed conference paper. There is an LTI form that must be filled out in advance.

qa_list.question: What should graduate students do if they need immediate funds for emergency situations?
qa_list.answer: They should contact the Office of the Dean of Students (see Appendix A), www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/index.html, to inquire about the types of emergency funding available to enrolled students.

qa_list.question: Is health insurance mandatory for full-time degree-seeking students at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Yes, all full-time, degree-seeking students are required to carry adequate medical insurance. They can either purchase the plan offered by the University or apply for a waiver if they meet certain conditions.

qa_list.question: What is the Carnegie Mellon Student Health Insurance Policy?
qa_list.answer: The policy requires full-time, degree-seeking students to carry adequate medical insurance. Students must either purchase the plan offered by the University or apply for a waiver if they are enrolled as dependents in an employer or government-sponsored insurance plan.

qa_list.question: What happens if students fail to obtain adequate medical insurance?
qa_list.answer: Students who do not comply with the Carnegie Mellon Student Health Insurance Policy may face penalties, such as being dropped from their courses or having their registration blocked.

qa_list.question: How can students apply for a waiver of the University's health insurance plan?
qa_list.answer: Students who are enrolled as dependents in an employer or government-sponsored insurance plan may apply for a waiver by submitting an online application through the Carnegie Mellon Student Health Insurance Policy website.

qa_list.question: What does the LTI cover?
qa_list.answer: The text states that the LTI (Long-Term Instruction) does not cover student health insurance, regardless of a student's funding situation.

qa_list.question: Who is responsible for making arrangements regarding student health insurance?
qa_list.answer: According to the text, it is the responsibility of each individual student to make arrangements with Student Health Services either to pay for their insurance at the beginning of the semester or elect a payment plan over the course of the academic year.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about student health services?
qa_list.answer: Students can obtain additional details regarding Student Health Services by visiting the website www.studentaffairs.cmu.edu/HealthServices/insurance, as mentioned in the text.

qa_list.question: What is the location of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The MLT Graduate Student Handbook can be found on Page 28, according to the given information.

qa_list.question: Does the LTI cover student health insurance for all students regardless of their funding situation?
qa_list.answer: No, the text explicitly states that the Long-Term Instruction (LTI) does not cover student health insurance, irrespective of a student's funding situation.

qa_list.question: What is the responsibility of Student Health Services regarding student health insurance?
qa_list.answer: Student Health Services has the responsibility to provide information about making arrangements for student health insurance at the beginning of each semester or elect a payment plan over the course of the academic year.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of providing more information on Student Health Services' website?
qa_list.answer: The additional details provided on the Student Health Services' website serve to inform students about their options and responsibilities regarding student health insurance, as mentioned in the text.

qa_list.question: What is the name of the page where more information about student health services can be found?
qa_list.answer: The specific web page containing additional details on Student Health Services is located at www.studentaffairs.cmu.edu/HealthServices/insurance.

qa_list.question: What does the MLT Graduate Student Handbook contain information about?
qa_list.answer: The text states that the MLT Graduate Student Handbook contains details regarding student health insurance and its coverage, as well as other relevant information for graduate students.

qa_list.question: What is the deadline to complete Form I-9 after starting a federally funded project?
qa_list.answer: Within three business days following the first day of stipend start date/employment.

qa_list.question: What happens if students fail to complete the Form I-9 in a timely manner?
qa_list.answer: Stipend payments may be suspended. If employed by the university, disciplinary action up to and including termination of employment may occur.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about Form I-9 and E-Verify requirements?
qa_list.answer: They can refer to CMU’s Guidance for Completing the Form I-9 and E-Verify Requirements at CMU [pdf] or visit the Human Resources Service website.

qa_list.question: What is The HUB Student Services Center?
qa_list.answer: The HUB provides comprehensive service and counsel to students and families regarding financial aid, billing and payment, registration and academic records. It's located in Warner Hall, Lower Level.

qa_list.question: Who are the contacts for specific colleges at The HUB?
qa_list.answer: The Assistant Directors in The HUB serve as contacts for specific colleges.

qa_list.question: Where can students find more information about MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: They can refer to the MLT Graduate Student Handbook, specifically Page 29.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the E-Verify Processing Request Form?
qa_list.answer: Individuals who expect to work on a federally funded project are responsible for submitting an E-Verify Processing Request Form if required.

qa_list.question: What is the location of The HUB Student Services Center?
qa_list.answer: The HUB is located in Warner Hall, Lower Level.

qa_list.question: How can students contact The HUB for assistance?
qa_list.answer: They can email at thehub@andrew.cmu.edu or visit http://www.cmu.edu/hub/

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of The HUB Assistant Directors at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The HUB Assistant Directors assist enrolled students with key aspects of the enrollment process.

qa_list.question: Where can students find their assigned HUB Assistant Director on their Student Information Online (SIO) Resource page?
qa_list.answer: Students can find their assigned HUB Assistant Director on their SIO Resource page.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Student Information Online (SIO)?
qa_list.answer: Student Information Online (SIO) is a secure site where students can find important, personalized information such as E-Bills and student account information, financial aid status and eligibility, grades and QPA, and course schedules.

qa_list.question: How do students log on to SIO?
qa_list.answer: Students can log on to SIO by going to www.cmu.edu/hub/sio and entering their Andrew User ID and password.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of designating an emergency contact address on SIO?
qa_list.answer: Students will designate an emergency contact address of a relative or family friend to be contacted in the case of an emergency.

qa_list.question: How can students prevent their name and address from being published in the campus directory?
qa_list.answer: If students do not want their name and address published in the campus directory, they must notify the HUB in writing.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students obtain their ID card at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can obtain their ID card from their program manager, department, or college.

qa_list.question: What happens to a student's ID card when they leave the university?
qa_list.answer: Student cards are deactivated upon the cardholder’s separation from the university.

qa_list.question: What is cross-registration and who is eligible for it?
qa_list.answer: Cross-registration provides an opportunity for enriched educational programs by permitting full-time graduate students to cross-register for courses (usually no more than one per semester) at a Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) Institution. Full-time Carnegie Mellon degree students are eligible and the PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they believe their education records are inaccurate or misleading?
qa_list.answer: Students have the right to inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.

qa_list.question: Can suspended students receive transfer credit?
qa_list.answer: Suspended students may take courses elsewhere, but they may receive transfer credit only if their college and department policies allow this.

qa_list.question: What is the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA)?
qa_list.answer: The federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) notifies students of their rights under FERPA. According to FERPA, students have the right to: inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction.

qa_list.question: What can students do if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated?
qa_list.answer: Students have the right to file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of cross-registration?
qa_list.answer: Cross-registration provides an opportunity for enriched educational programs by permitting full-time graduate students to cross-register for courses (usually no more than one per semester) at a Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) Institution.

qa_list.question: Can PCHE course taken through cross-registration count towards full-time status?
qa_list.answer: Full-time Carnegie Mellon degree students are eligible for cross-registration, and the PCHE course may not count towards full-time status unless the student is enrolled in an inter-university program.

qa_list.question: What should students do if they want to take advantage of the cross-registration opportunity?
qa_list.answer: Students interested in taking advantage of this opportunity should be familiar with the Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses already outlined previously in this handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the policy on grades for transfer courses?
qa_list.answer: The policy on grades for transfer courses varies by institution and program, but generally requires a minimum grade of C or better to be transferred.

qa_list.question: Who should students contact for questions about Student Privacy Rights, FERPA or filing a complaint?
qa_list.answer: John Papinchak, University Registrar in Enrollment Services

qa_list.question: Where can students find the official academic calendar at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The official academic calendar is published by Enrollment Services and can be found on www.cmu.edu/hub/calendar.html.

qa_list.question: What department handles academic requirements that differ from or are in addition to those presented in the academic calendar?
qa_list.answer: Departments and colleges

qa_list.question: Who is responsible for providing professional development opportunities at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The Career Center provides professional development opportunities.

qa_list.question: What can students find on the CMU academic calendar website?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about deadlines including registration dates, class start dates, add/drop deadlines, and more.

qa_list.question: Where should students go for questions related to Student Privacy Rights, FERPA or filing a complaint?
qa_list.answer: Students can contact John Papinchak, University Registrar in Enrollment Services.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the Career Center at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The Career Center provides professional development opportunities for students.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about academic requirements that differ from or are in addition to those presented in the academic calendar?
qa_list.answer: Students should check with their departments and colleges.

qa_list.question: What is the official source of CMU's academic calendar information?
qa_list.answer: The official source for CMU's academic calendar information is Enrollment Services.

5.1.5 Transfer Credit
An equivalent graduate course previously completed at another institution may be permitted to satisfy one of the MLT course requirements. The decision on whether a course may be transferred is made by the MLT Program Director. Typically, the student will provide the Program Director with the syllabus of the external course, and the Program Director will use that and the student’s transcript to make the decision.

5.1.6 External Internships
MLT students may only engage in internships if their advisors recommend it, since the program is 24 months, including summers. International students are required to consult with the Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract.
We caution all students to be aware of potential intellectual property (IP) problems with internships, and to review any IP agreements with their advisors before signing them. It is possible to lose ownership of your ideas.
Important: See also section 4.2.3, External Employment/Consulting.

5.1.7 Transferring Into the MLT Program
Transfers into the MLT program are not permitted during a student’s first semester at CMU. Students must begin their study at CMU in the program that admitted them; this is a university policy.
Students may request to transfer into the MLT program after completing their first semester. The student must make the request in writing (or email) to the MLT/PhD Admissions Chair. The MLT/PhD Admissions Chair will inform the student about what application materials are required; for example, an explanation of why a transfer is desired, a proposed plan of study, a proposed advisor, and CMU transcripts. Students that are already enrolled in an LTI degree program are not required to retake GRE and TOEFL exams or to produce new transcripts from other universities. The MLT program will conduct an expedited admissions process after receiving such a request.
5.1.8 Transferring Out of the MLT Program
The MLT program does not prevent students from transferring to another degree program. Each degree program has its own rules about whether and when transfers into the program are permitted. A student that is interested in transferring out of the MLT degree program should consult the handbook and Program Director of the desired degree program to learn whether transfers are permitted, and if so, how and when to request such a transfer.
5.1.9 Drop/Add/Withdraw Procedures
Students taking undergraduate and Masters’ level courses must follow the procedures and deadlines for adding, dropping, and withdrawing from courses as identified on the academic calendar. Information can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/course- changes.index. Please note that there is a separate calendar for doctoral courses that does not apply to Masters’ students.
5.1.10 Statute of Limitations
As outlined in the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations, https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of- limitations.html. Students will complete all requirements for the masters’ degree within a maximum of seven years from original matriculation as a masters’ student, or less if required by a more restrictive department, school, or college policy. Once this time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a masters’ degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered masters’ degree program under criteria determined by that program.
See also the ‘Duration of Study’ policy.

5.1.11 Teaching Requirements
MLT students do not normally serve as Teaching Assistants (TAs). If an MLT student wants to TA a course, they must get the approval of their research advisor.
In the unusual case of an MLT student TAing, note that graduate students are required to have a certain level of fluency in English before they can instruct in Pennsylvania, as required by the English Fluency in Higher Education Act of 1990. Through this Act, all institutions of higher education in the state are required to evaluate and certify the English fluency of all instructional personnel, including teaching assistants and interns. The full University policy can be reviewed at https://www.cmu.edu/policies/faculty/evaluation-certification-english-fluency- instructors.html.
The fluency of all instructional personnel will be rated by Language Support in the Student Academic Success Center to determine at what level of responsibility the student can TA. In addition to administering the International Teaching Assistant (ITA) Test (a mandatory screening for all non-native speakers of English), Language Support in the Student Academic Success Center helps teaching assistants who are non-native English speakers develop fluency and cultural understanding to teach successfully at Carnegie Mellon. Visit the Student Academic Success Center website for additional information: https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/.
5.2 LTI Academic Policies
5.2.1 “Grandfather” policy
A student can graduate under the policies in effect at the time that the student entered the program; or, at the student's choice, the student can graduate under policies that are adopted after the student entered the program. If it is not realistic to follow a particular policy exactly, the department may approximate the policy as closely as possible; this situation is rare and typically arises only when a student is enrolled in the program for an extended period of time.
5.2.2 Definition of transfer credit versus course exemption
The LTI may grant transfer credit or issue an exemption for equivalent graduate courses previously completed at another institution. This decision rests with the chair of the particular program. If a student is exempt from a required course due to prior courses or experience, the student can replace that course with an open elective. The student does not receive credit for the external course, but can take any course that could normally count toward the degree in its place. If a student receives credit for prior coursework completed at CMU or elsewhere, the student receives that many units of credit, and the total amount of required coursework is reduced by that amount.
MLT Graduate Student Handbook

5.2.3 External Employment/Consulting
Students funded by LTI research projects are normally expected to work exclusively for those projects. Since consulting may provide useful experience, students are generally permitted to consult, at most, one eight-hour day per seven-day week, only with the advisor's consent. International students must also have approval in advance from the Office of International Education (OIE); otherwise, they may be in violation of their visa status.
Important: Any work for pay outside of the funding research project must be approved in advance by the advisor (and OIE, for international students). This includes paid TAing, consulting, online free-lancing, etc.
5.2.4 Leave of Absence
The LTI discourages Leaves of Absence (LOA), since students usually do not return, despite good intentions. However, a student in good standing may be granted a LOA of at most 1 year, upon written request to the Program Director and with consent of the student's advisor. It is the responsibility of the student on LOA to contact the LTI to initiate a return to the program.
5.2.5 Satisfactory Progress
If a student does not make satisfactory progress each semester toward completing the degree, the LTI may remove the student from the program. See section on “End of Semester Evaluation.”
5.2.6 Winter and Summer Breaks
Students supported by research projects are expected to remain on campus working during breaks in classes. A two-week vacation is typically allowed in the summer. The normal winter break policy is that the student works 40 hours per week for two weeks, and takes vacation for the other two weeks.

Short-term accommodation for gestational parents – A short-term absence from academic responsibilities up to a maximum of six (6) weeks. 6.1 Graduate Student Funding
For all LTI MLT students, full funding (tuition plus stipend) is guaranteed for the first year. This support is normally continued for the duration of the program, subject to continuing satisfactory progress and availability of funding. The fellowship includes full tuition and fees, and a monthly MLT stipend. In addition, the LTI pays a dependency allowance of 10% of the student's monthly stipend to any student with a child, unless they have a spouse who earns more than $200 per month.
If an MLT student receives an outside graduate fellowship (e.g., NSF, Fulbright), the student is expected to accept it in place of the LTI’s graduate fellowship. As an extra incentive to do so, the LTI will supplement the award so that the student will receive full tuition and a combined

7.6 Student Privacy Rights and FERPA
www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/StPrivacy.html This university policy notifies students of their rights under the federal Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). According to FERPA, students have the right to:
•
inspect and review their education records; request an amendment to their education record if they believe they are inaccurate or misleading; request a hearing if their request for an amendment is not resolved to their satisfaction;
• consent to disclosure of personally identifiable information from their education records, except to the extent that FERPA authorizes disclosure without consent; file a complaint with the U.S. Department of Education Family Policy Compliance Office if they believe their rights under FERPA have been violated.
